Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 46196 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
August 2012 
 
 
 
Global Supply Chains and Trade in Value Added
 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
ADBI  –  Asian Development Bank Institute 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  GSC  –  global supply chain 
  IDE-JETRO  –  Institute of Developing Economies, Japan External Trade Organization

Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Chief Economist  C. Y. Rhee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
Assistant Chief Economist  J. Zveglich, Jr., Macroeconomics and Finance Research

Team member  C. Petalcorin, Economics Officer, ERD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

1   
I.   INTRODUCTION  
1.  The fragmentation of production processes and the rise of global supply chains (GSCs) 
since the 1980s have become increasingly important factors in linking developing countries to 
international production networks and markets. Today, a large share of production within GSCs 
takes place in developing countries, especially in East Asia and Southeast Asia.  
2.  Strategy 2020 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) emphasizes the “great promise 
that regional cooperation and integration activities present for accelerating economic growth, 
raising productivity and employment, reducing economic disparities, and achieving closer policy 
coordination and collaboration in support of regional and global public goods.”1 The technical 
assistance (TA) contributes to this strategic priority by shedding light on poorly understood 
aspects of the regional integration of production and by raising the capacity of ADB to formulate 
policy advice on the basis of state-of-the-art data and methods for the analysis of GSCs in the 
region.  In  cooperation  with  other  organizations—the  Fung  Global  Institute;  the  Institute  of 
Developing Economies, Japan External Trade Organization (IDE-JETRO); the Organisation for 
Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD); and the World Trade Organization (WTO)—
the TA will facilitate ADB’s establishment as a contributing member within the nascent research 
consortium focusing on these issues.2  
II.   ISSUES 
3.  The international fragmentation of production has created the need for new measures of 
trade that account for the value that is actually added by a country to the goods or services it 
exports, net of the imported value of intermediate parts and components, i.e., trade in value 
added (TVA). By contrast, traditional trade statistics reflect gross value, thus double-counting 
the  value  of  intermediates  as  they  cross  international  borders  multiple  times.  As  a  result, 
international trade statistics provide an inaccurate picture of trade involving heavily networked 
economies. For example, domestic value added is estimated to account for roughly 60% of the 
exports value of the People’s Republic of China while its trade surplus with the United States is 
thought to be overestimated by about 40%.3 Only by duly accounting for TVA can ADB research 
and policy advice be made reflective of the economic and social implications of production 
networks in the region. Moreover, TVA analysis assesses the impact of foreign demand or 
supply shocks, such as those triggered by recent natural disasters in Japan and Thailand, as 
they propagate through GSCs. 
4.  Analytical issues concern mainly the measurement of GSCs and vertical specialization 
(the foreign value added embedded within exports). The main approaches are (i) input–output 
analysis, associating inputs with industry outputs and identifying the source of those inputs; 
(ii) defining product categories using some descriptors like “parts and components”; (iii) firm-
level data on foreign inputs, tracking both foreign input purchases and exports by firms; (iv) the 
use of processing trade data, such as are available for the People’s Republic of China, to 
assess the value added on imported goods that are officially designated for further processing 
and re-export; (v) multinational firm data, especially datasets that provide information on affiliate

Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 10 July 2012. 
3  R. Koopman et al. 2010. Give Credit Where Credit Is Due: Tracing Value Added in Global Production Chains. 
NBER Working Paper Series. No. w16426. Cambridge: National Bureau of Economic Research; R.C. Johnson and 
G. Noguera. 2012. Accounting for Intermediates: Production Sharing and Trade in Value Added. Journal of 
International Economics. 86(2). March 2012.

2   
sales  or  intra-firm  trade.  The  TA  will  compare  the  strengths  and  weaknesses  of  these 
approaches with special reference to Asia’s role in GSCs. 
5.  A further issue concerns the assessment of the determinants and structure of GSCs. 
Such analysis typically has used measures of TVA as the dependent variable in regression 
analysis focused on understanding if trade of this sort behaves differently from other trade, e.g., 
is more sensitive to trade costs. The literature is still extremely thin on these issues and the TA 
can do much to shed light on the drivers of and impediments to GSCs and TVA in Asia.  
6.  Finally, there is a key issue concerning offshoring and its effects on firms and labor 
markets. Such analysis has to rely mainly on firm-level data, which is becoming increasingly 
available. Because these datasets also include firm-level characteristics and are in some cases 
linked to employment databases, analysis can now go much further in understanding why 
individual firms choose to produce with foreign value added, and how this affects their outcomes 
(e.g., in productivity or wages). 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The TA will bring ADB’s Economics and Research Department (ERD) up to speed with 
the recent advances in the methods and data for the analysis of TVA and GSCs, so its research 
outputs can better support policymaking in developing member countries (DMCs). Based on the 
latest international input–output tables, multinational firm data on foreign inputs, processing 
trade data, and incorporating recent progress by scholarly research in the field, the TA will seek 
to develop tools for TVA analysis that shed light on Asia’s supply chains, their determinants, and 
their impact on development in Asia. Apart from publishing findings in working papers and in a 
volume targeted at both scholarly and policy-oriented audiences, the TA will establish ADB as a 
recognized research partner of the nascent consortium of organizations and think tanks that 
collaborate in this field (such as ADBI, the Fung Global Institute, IDE-JETRO, OECD, and 
WTO). 
8.  The impact will be greater awareness of DMC policymakers of the nature and impact of 
global supply chains in national economic growth and development. The outcome will be a 
deeper understanding of the nature and role of GSCs and TVA as it involves DMCs and 
developing Asia as a region.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will conduct selected case studies of GSCs in Asia through joint research and 
publications with partner organizations in the region. In addition, it will hire leading experts of 
global value chain analysis as authors for an ADB book project on GSCs in Asia. Research is 
envisaged to focus on the following:4 
(i)  Measurement methods. Review alternative approaches to measuring TVA and 
latest data available for analysis and assess how methodological choices reflect 
on Asia’s representation within GSCs. 
(ii)  Correlates and determinants of GSCs and TVA. Inferential analysis with a 
focus on pertinent policy links, such as whether GSCs are more sensitive to 
infrastructure, trade facilitation indicators, or exchange rate variability. In addition, 
                                                 
4 This is an interim list subject to change. A refined research agenda for individual chapters will be determined by the 
fourth quarter of 2012.

3 
TVA measures will be used to empirically review our perceptions on key policy 
issues for the region, such as exchange rate pass-through or the responsiveness 
of trade to tariff liberalization.  
(iii)  Concept of “labor value added in trade.” For countries employing borrowed 
capital  in  production,  the  concept  of  “domestic  value  added”  represents  an 
inaccurate metric as it incorporates both labor and capital. TA research will thus 
attempt to refocus input–output analysis on the value added by purely local factor 
inputs, mainly labor. Relevant policy implications will be discussed.  
(iv)  Supply chain disruptions and demand shocks. Analyze the impact of supply 
shocks on GSCs, whether caused by natural disasters or ascribable to principal-
agent issues, and also of demand shocks (e.g., recessions, secular declines of 
an industry) radiating up the supply chain. Research will also assess the risks 
and  benefits  associated  with  alternative  diversification  strategies  for  Asian 
suppliers within GSCs and derive policy conclusions.  
(v)  Role of services in supply chains. Assess key GSC services in Asia, such as 
cargo transportation, passenger aviation, business services (finance, marketing, 
intermediation),  and  discuss  the  need  for  policy  reforms  that  are  sufficiently 
broad-based to include services.  
(vi)  Location analysis of industries’ position. Build on recently devised measures 
of a country’s position within GSCs and assess DMC potential and hindrances to 
moving upstream. 
(vii)  TVA-corrected  macroeconomic  indicators.  Determine  international  trade’s 
contribution  to  economic  growth,  the  extent  of  bilateral  trade  balances,  or 
exchange rates. Again, with focus on DMCs.  
(viii)  International trade regulations and regional agreements. Working papers on 
the impact of international trade regulations and regional agreements on GSCs 
and TVA, arising out of the TA as well as partnering organizations’ research 
activities in this field, for discussion at joint conferences during the course of this 
project. 
 
10.  A better understanding of the nature and role of GSCs and TVA as it involves DMCs and 
developing Asia as a region (the expected outcome of the TA) will be achieved through the 
publication of a TA book, working papers and other publications (the expected outputs), the 
findings of which will be disseminated through conferences and seminars. 
11.  The TA rests on the assumptions that (i) top experts, including a lead economist, can be 
hired  to  provide  technical  inputs  and  write  research  papers  of  the  highest  professional 
standards; (ii) the TA volume will be accepted by a leading publisher; (iii) the findings will 
resonate  in  the  rhetoric  and  policy  of  relevant  international  and  national  institutions  and 
organizations, as well as in DMC government circles.  
12.  The key risks are that (i) leading experts cannot be hired for some of the subprojects 
envisioned for the TA; (ii) ERD will not sufficiently absorb the technologies introduced by the TA, 
and will be unable to reflect them in policy notes, reports, and working papers; and (iii) the data 
(international  input–output,  processing  trade,  firm-level)  available  for  research  have  limited 
coverage on DMCs or are of low quality.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–IV).

4   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months (1 September 2012–31 August 2014). ADB, 
through ERD’s Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division, will be the executing agency. 
ERD will also cooperate with OREI and ADBI, in particular by seeking their comments on drafts 
and their involvement in conferences as discussants or with their own papers on the topic.   
15.  The TA will engage individual consultants with demonstrated expertise on GSC and TVA 
analysis, and trade empirics more broadly. Individual hiring is justified by the need to engage 
the best experts available in this highly specialized field of research. The TA will first hire a lead 
economist who will be an established expert in international input–output and GSC analysis. 
The lead economist will assist the ADB team leader in specifying detailed research plans and 
subsequently coordinating the inputs of the consultants hired as authors of chapters for the TA 
volume. In addition, the TA will hire experts for preparing up to two case studies in collaboration 
with  partner  organizations  such  as  the  Fung  Global  Institute.  Overall,  the  TA  will  engage 
13.5 person-months  of  international  consultant  inputs  and  3–6  person-months  of  national 
consultant  inputs.  The  team  leader  will  manage  the  combined  outputs  to  achieve  the  TA 
objectives.  
16.  Consultants’ terms of reference are outlined in Appendix 3. Individual consultants will be 
engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be in accordance with ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended time to time). All the procurement to be 
financed under the TA will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  TA  will  coordinate  arrangements  for  external 
publications with ADB’s Department of External Relations.  
17.  The TA will explore opportunities for joint research, publications, and dissemination 
events with partner institutions such as ADBI, the Fung Global Institute, IDE-JETRO, OECD, 
and WTO. The proposed work and responsibilities will be divided among the partners, which will 
control and allocate their own resources.  
18.  The ADB team leader will monitor and evaluate the progress of the consultants hired, 
with the support of the lead economist. The primary mechanism for disseminating the research 
findings will be a book publication, ERD working papers, and inputs to the Asian Development 
Outlook.5 In addition to publications, the TA will conduct workshops and conferences, jointly with 
the use of mass media for a broader dissemination of the TA outputs. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Global Supply Chains and Trade in Value Added, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

7  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consultants will be engaged on an individual basis to provide technical services under 
the technical assistance (TA) for Global Supply Chains and Trade in Value Added, and will 
report  to  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  team  leader.  The  TA  will  hire  international 
consultants (total of 13.5 person-months) and a national consultant (3–6 person-months).  
 
A.  International Consultants  
 
2.  Nine or more of the international consultants will be economists with a demonstrated 
experience in the analysis of trade in value added (TVA) and global supply chains (GSCs) 
based  on  international  input–output  tables  and/or  international  trade  data.  As  a  minimum 
qualification, these international consultants will have a master’s degree (PhD preferred) or, 
equivalently,  10  years  of  relevant  professional  experience.  In  addition,  one  international 
consultant  will  be  an  experienced  economics  editor  with  a  professional  track  record  of 
publications with leading international publishers. 
 
3.  Lead economist (3 person-months, 1 consultant). Under the supervision of the ADB 
team leader, the lead economist will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)   Lead a team of economists engaged by the TA to define the data sources 
required for analysis and assist in setting up the data and a state-of-the-art 
analytical framework for analysis.  
(ii)  Perform and supervise TA economists’ empirical analysis on the topics assigned. 
(iii)  Coordinate and adjust the focus of research in view of the broader efforts within 
the research consortium the TA will partner with, and clearly identify the links 
between the TA and broader research efforts in the field.  
(iv)  On  the  basis  of  (i)–(iii)  above,  contribute  to  fostering  the  capacity  of  ADB’s 
Economics and Research Department (ERD) to analyze GSC implications for 
growth and development in developing member countries (DMCs). 
 (v)  Write technical research papers and coordinate TA economists’ contributions 
toward a TA book that derives a pertinent set of policy conclusions incorporating 
(i)–(iv). The papers will become chapters in the TA book and may also serve as 
inputs to the Asian Development Outlook.1 
(vi)    Coordinate and support the team of economists in finalizing annotated research 
plans in relation to the topics assigned at the inception workshop, reviewing 
advanced draft papers during the course of the TA, and ensuring that comments 
from the workshops and by the ADB team leader are incorporated in the final 
drafts for publication in the TA book. 
(vii)  Present the research findings at the TA conference to be held in Q4 2013.  
  
4.  Economists (9 person-months, 8 or more consultants). Eight (or more, depending on 
task assignments and profiles hired) international economists will prepare case studies and 
empirical or policy-oriented research papers focusing on GSCs and TVA. Case studies will be 
prepared in collaboration with research partners. Under the guidance of the ADB team leader 
and  the  lead  economist,  for  each  topic,  the  economists  working  on  the  book  project  will 
undertake the following tasks:  
(i)  Define the data sources required for analysis and assist in acquiring and setting 
up the data and analytical framework.  
                                                 
1  ADB. Asian Development Outlook. http://www.adb.org/publications/series/asian-development-outlook

8  Appendix 3 
 
 
(ii)  Perform rigorous empirical analysis on the topic assigned, reflecting the latest 
methodological advances in the field (in coordination with the lead economist, 
partner organizations, and members of the broader research community, or as 
requested by the ADB team leader). 
(iii)  Clearly identify the links between this specific approach and the broader research 
efforts conducted both within the TA and by partner organizations.  
(iv)  On the basis of (i)–(iii) above, contribute to fostering ERD’s capacity to analyze 
GSCs in Asia and their impact on economic development in the region. 
(v)  Write empirical or policy-oriented research papers on the topics assigned and 
derive a pertinent set of policy conclusions that incorporates (i)–(iv). The papers 
will become chapters in the TA book and may also serve as inputs to the Asian 
Development Outlook. 
(vi)  Present annotated research plans at the TA inception workshop, for review by 
the ADB team leader and the lead economist. More advanced draft papers and 
progress  reports  will  later  be  presented  at  TA  workshops  (which  may  be 
conducted via online conferencing) or conferences and seminars (which may be 
held jointly with partner organizations). Final drafts submitted for publication in 
the TA book are expected to fully incorporate the comments received by the lead 
economist and the ADB team leader. 
 
5.  Manuscript editor (1.5 person-months, 1 consultant). The manuscript editor will review 
and  edit  drafts  and  manuscripts  in  coordination  with  the  authors,  adhering  to  the  highest 
publication standards and the ADB Handbook of Style and Usage.2 In particular, the editor will 
undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Rewrite, reorganize, and shorten the text to improve logical structure; cut or edit 
redundant  pages  and  simplify  long,  complicated  sentences;  smoothen  the 
transitions between paragraphs and sections; and ensure that language style is 
consistent across the book chapters. 
(ii)  Examine tables and figures to ensure data consistency within the book chapters. 
(iii)  Check all references to tables, figures, appendixes, bibliographies, footnotes, 
citations, and references. 
(iv)  Ensure that the manuscript conforms to the ADB Handbook of Style and Usage. 
(v)  Liaise between the publisher, the ADB team leader, and the contributing authors.  
(vi)  Assist with all aspects of the publication process and maintain a tight timeline for 
the book’s completion and publication according to set deadlines. 
(vii)  Provide other editorial inputs as required. 
 
B.  National Consultant  
 
6.  Research economist (3–6 person-months, 1 consultant). A research economist with a 
strong background in empirical trade analysis will be hired on a part-time basis at the ADB 
headquarters to assist in the TA research work on TVA and GSCs. In particular, the economist 
will undertake the following tasks:  
(i)  Support the preparation of data, empirical analysis, and provide other inputs for 
research. 
(ii)  Provide  technical  support  to  both  international  consultants  and  ADB  staff  in 
implementing the TA. 
(iii)  Support other tasks as assigned.
